text: Some men came down from the country of Judea and started to teach the Christians. They said, “Unless you go through the religious act of becoming a Jew as Moses taught, you cannot be saved from the punishment of sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Barnabas argued with them. Then Paul and Barnabas and some other men were chosen to go up to Jerusalem. They were to talk to the missionaries and church leaders about this teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: The church sent them on their way. They went through the countries of Phoenicia and Samaria and told how those who were not Jews were turning to God. This made the Christians very happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they got to Jerusalem, the church and the missionaries and the church leaders were glad to see them. Paul and Barnabas told them what God had done through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Christians there had been proud religious law-keepers. They got up and said, “Doing the religious act of becoming a Jew and keeping the Law of Moses are two things that must be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The missionaries and church leaders got together to talk about this.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a long time of much talking, Peter got up and said to them, “Brothers, you know in the early days God was pleased to use me to preach the Good News to the people who are not Jews so they might put their trust in Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: God knows the hearts of all men. He showed them they were to have His loving-favor by giving them the Holy Spirit the same as He gave to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has made no difference between them and us. They had their hearts made clean when they put their trust in Him also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you test God by putting too heavy a load on the back of the followers? It was too heavy for our fathers or for us to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: We believe it is by the loving-favor of the Lord Jesus that we are saved. They are saved from the punishment of sin the same way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All those who were gathered together said nothing. They listened to Paul and Barnabas who told of the powerful works God had done through them among the people who are not Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they finished speaking, James said, “Brothers, listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simon Peter has told how God first visited the people who are not Jews. He was getting a people for Himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: This agrees with what the early preacher said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ’After this I will come back and build again the building of David that fell down. Yes, I will build it again from the stones that fell down. I will set it up again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the nations may look for the Lord, even all the people who are not Jews who are called by My name. The Lord said this. He does all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has made all His works known from the beginning of time.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So we should not trouble these people who are not Jews who are turning to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: We should write to them that they should keep away from everything that is given to gods. They should keep away from sex sins and not eat blood or meat from animals that have been killed in ways against the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Law of Moses has been read in every city from the early days. It has been read in the Jewish places of worship on every Day of Rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the missionaries and the church leaders and the whole church chose some men from among them. They were to be sent to the city of Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas Barsabbas and Silas. These men were leaders among the Christians.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent them with this letter: “The missionaries and church leaders and Christians greet the brothers who are not Jews in Antioch and Syria and Cilicia.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have heard that some from our group have troubled you and have put doubt in your minds. They said that you must go through the religious act of becoming a Jew and you must keep the Law of Moses. We did not tell them to say these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of us have wanted to send men to you with our much-loved Paul and Barnabas.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their lives have been in danger for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now we send Judas and Silas to you. They will tell you the same things.
speaker: Narrator

text: It pleased the Holy Spirit and us to ask you to do nothing more than these things that have to be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to keep away from everything that is given to gods. Do not eat blood or meat from animals that have been killed in ways against the Law. Keep away from sex sins. If you keep yourselves free from these things you will do well. Good-by.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the meeting was finished, they went to Antioch. As soon as they gathered the people together, they gave them the letter.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they read it, they were glad for the comfort and strength it brought them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judas and Silas were preachers also. They preached to the Christians and helped them to become stronger in the faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were there for some time. Then they were sent back in peace to the missionaries who had sent them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Silas thought he should stay there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Barnabas stayed in Antioch. With the help of many others, they preached and taught the Word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: After awhile, Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us go back and visit the Christians in every city where we have preached the Word of God. Let us see how they are doing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barnabas wanted to take John Mark with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul did not think it was good to take him because he had left them while they were in Pamphylia. He had not helped them in the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: They argued so much that they left each other. Barnabas took John Mark with him and went by ship to the island of Cyprus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul chose Silas. After the Christians asked for the Lord’s favor to be on Paul and Silas, they went on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went through Syria and Cilicia making the churches stronger in the faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went down to the cities of Derbe and Lystra. There was a follower there named Timothy. His mother was a Jewish Christian and his father was a Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Christians in the city of Lystra and Iconium respected Timothy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul wanted Timothy to go with him as a missionary. He took him and had Timothy go through the religious act of becoming a Jew because of the Jews who were in those places. Everyone knew his father was a Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went from city to city and told the Christians what the missionaries and the church leaders in Jerusalem had written for the Christians to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The churches were made stronger in the faith. More people were added each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went through the countries of Phrygia and Galatia. The Holy Spirit kept them from preaching the Word of God in the countries of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the city of Mysia, they tried to go on to the city of Bithynia but the Holy Spirit would not let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Mysia they went down to the city of Troas.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night Paul had a dream. A man was standing in front of him crying out, “Come over to the country of Macedonia and help us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had seen this, we agreed that God told us to go to Macedonia to tell them the Good News.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took a ship from the city of Troas to the city of Samothracia. The next day we went to the city of Neapolis.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we went to the city of Philippi. This was an important city in Macedonia. It was ruled by the leaders of the country of Rome. We stayed here for some days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the Day of Rest we went outside the city to a place down by the river. We thought people would be gathering there for prayer. Some women came and we sat down and talked to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the women who listened sold purple cloth. She was from the city of Thyatira. Her name was Lydia and she was a worshiper of God. The Lord opened her heart to hear what Paul said.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she and her family had been baptized, she said to us, “If you think I am faithful to the Lord, come and stay at my house.” She kept on asking. Then we went with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as we were going to the place to pray, we met a servant-girl who could tell what was going to happen in the future by a demon she had. Her owner made much money from her power.
speaker: Narrator

text: She followed Paul and us crying out, “These are servants of the Highest God. They are telling you how to be saved from the punishment of sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She did this many days. Paul was troubled. Then he turned and said to the demon in her, “In the name of Jesus Christ, I speak to you. Come out of her!” At once it left her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The girl’s owners saw that they could not make money with her anymore. Then they took hold of Paul and Silas and dragged them to the leaders. This happened in the center of town where people gather.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they brought them in front of the leaders, they said, “These men are Jews and are making a lot of trouble in our city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are teaching a religion that we Romans are not allowed to follow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Many people had gathered around Paul and Silas. They were calling out things against them. The leaders had the clothes of Paul and Silas taken off and had them beaten with sticks.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had hit them many times, they put Paul and Silas in prison. The soldiers told the man who watched the prison to be sure to keep them from getting away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this, they were put in the inside room of the prison and their feet were put in pieces of wood that held them.
speaker: Narrator

text: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing songs of thanks to God. The other men in prison were listening to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All at once the earth started to shake. The stones under the prison shook and the doors opened. The chains fell off from everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who watched the prison woke up. He saw the prison doors wide open and thought the men in prison had gotten away. At once he pulled out his sword to kill himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul called to him, “Do not hurt yourself. We are all here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who watched the prison called for a light. Then he ran in and got down in front of Paul and Silas. He was shaking with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he took them outside, he said, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Put your trust in the Lord Jesus Christ and you and your family will be saved from the punishment of sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul spoke the Word of God to him and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was late at night, but the man who watched the prison took Paul and Silas in and washed the places on their bodies where they were hurt. Right then he and his family were baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took Paul and Silas to his house and gave them food. He and all his family were full of joy for having put their trust in God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was day, the leaders sent a soldier to say, “Let these men go free.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who watched the prison told this to Paul. He said, “The leaders have sent word to let you go free. Come out now and go without any trouble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “No! They have beaten us in front of many people without a trial. We are Roman citizens and they have put us in prison. Now do they think they can send us away without anyone knowing? No! They must come themselves and take us out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers told this to the leaders. Then the leaders were afraid when they heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went themselves and told Paul and Silas they were sorry. Then they took them out and asked them to leave their city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul and Silas went to Lydia’s house after they left the prison. They met with the Christians and gave them comfort. Then they went away from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Paul and Silas had gone through the cities of Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to the city of Thessalonica. The Jews had a place of worship there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went in as he always did. They gathered together each Day of Rest for three weeks and he taught them from the Holy Writings.
speaker: Narrator

text: He showed them that Christ had to suffer and rise again from the dead. He said, “I preach this Jesus to you. He is the Christ.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of them put their trust in Christ and followed Paul and Silas. There were many Greek people and some leading women who honored God among those who had become Christians.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews who did not put their trust in Christ became jealous. They took along some sinful men from the center of town where people gather and brought them out on the street. These angry men started all the people in the city to cry out with loud voices. They went to the house of Jason hoping to find Paul and Silas there and bring them out to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not find them there. Then they dragged Jason and some other Christians out in front of the leaders and cried out, “These men who have been making trouble over all the world have come here also.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jason has taken them in. They say there is another King called Jesus. They are working against the laws made by Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people and city leaders heard this, they were troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they made Jason and the others pay some money and let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: At once the Christians sent Paul and Silas away at night to the city of Berea. When they got there, they went to the Jewish place of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: These Jews were more willing to understand than those in the city of Thessalonica. They were very glad to hear the Word of God, and they looked into the Holy Writings to see if those things were true.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of them became Christians. Some of them were respected Greek women and men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews of Thessalonica heard that Paul was preaching the Word of God in Berea. They went there and worked against the missionaries by talking to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: At once the Christians sent Paul away to the sea-shore. But Silas and Timothy stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who took Paul brought him to the city of Athens. Paul sent word with them that Silas and Timothy should come to him as soon as they could. Then they left.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Paul was waiting for Silas and Timothy in Athens, his spirit was troubled as he saw the whole city worshiping false gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: He talked to the Jews and other people who were worshiping in the Jewish place of worship. Every day he talked with people who gathered in the center of town.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men from two different groups were arguing with Paul. The one group thought that men might as well get all the fun out of life that they can. The other group thought that wisdom alone makes men happy. Some of them said, “This man has lots of little things to talk about. They are not important. What is he trying to say?” Others said, “He preaches about strange gods.” It was because he preached of Jesus and of His being raised from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took him to Mars’ Hill and said, “We want to hear of this new teaching of yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the things you are telling us are strange to our ears. We want to know what these things mean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Athens and those visiting from far countries used all their time in talking or hearing some new thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul stood up on Mars’ Hill and said, “Men of Athens, I see how very religious you are in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I was walking around and looking at the things you worship, I found an altar where you worship with the words written on it, TO THE GOD WHO IS NOT KNOWN. You are worshiping Him without knowing Him. He is the One I will tell you about.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The God Who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth. He does not live in buildings made by hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one needs to care for Him as if He needed anything. He is the One who gives life and breath and everything to everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made from one blood all nations who live on the earth. He set the times and places where they should live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They were to look for God. Then they might feel after Him and find Him because He is not far from each one of us.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is in Him that we live and move and keep on living. Some of your own men have written, ‘We are God’s children.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If we are God’s children, we should not think of Him as being like gold or silver or stone. Such gods made of gold or silver or stone are planned by men and are made by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “God did not remember these times when people did not know better. But now He tells all men everywhere to be sorry for their sins and to turn from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has set a day when He will say in the right way if the people of the world are guilty. This will be done by Jesus Christ, the One He has chosen. God has proven this to all men by raising Jesus Christ from the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some people laughed and made fun when they heard Paul speak of Christ being raised from the dead. Others said, “We want to listen to you again about this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Paul went away from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some people followed him and became Christians. One was Dionysius, a leader in the city. A woman named Damaris believed. And there were others also.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that Paul went from the city of Athens and came to the city of Corinth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He met a Jew there named Aquila who was born in the country of Pontus. He had lived in the country of Italy a short time. His wife Priscilla was with him. Claudius, who was the leader of the country, had told all the Jews to leave Rome. Paul went to see Aquila and Priscilla.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made tents for a living. Paul did the same kind of work so he stayed with them and they worked together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every Day of Rest he would go to the Jewish place of worship and teach both Jews and Greeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Silas and Timothy came down from the country of Macedonia. Then Paul used all his time preaching to the Jews. He taught that Jesus was the Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they worked against Paul and said bad things about him. He shook his clothes and said, “Whatever happens to you is your own doing. I am free from your guilt. From now on I will go to the people who are not Jews.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went from there and came to the house of a man named Titus Justus who worshiped God. His house was next to the Jewish place of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crispus was the leader of the Jewish place of worship. He and his family believed in the Lord. Many of the people of Corinth who heard Paul became Christians and were baptized.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul saw the Lord in a dream one night. He said to Paul, “Do not be afraid. Keep speaking. Do not close your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am with you. No one will hurt you. I have many people in this city who belong to Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For a year and a half Paul stayed there and taught them the Word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gallio was leader of the country of Greece. All the Jews worked against Paul and brought him in front of the court.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “This man is trying to get people to worship God against the Law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul was ready to speak, but Gallio said to the Jews, “If this were something bad or a wrong doing, I would listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because it is about words and names and your own Law, you will have to take care of it yourselves. I do not want to judge who is right or wrong in things like this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sent them out of his court.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the Greek people took Sosthenes, the leader of the Jewish place of worship, and beat him in front of the court. But Gallio did not let this trouble him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul stayed in Corinth many days longer. Then he said good-bye and left the followers. He went by ship to the country of Syria with Priscilla and Aquila going with him. In the city of Cenchrea he had his hair cut short because of a promise he had made to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to the city of Ephesus. Priscilla and Aquila stayed there. Paul went to the Jewish place of worship and argued with the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: They wanted him to stay longer but he would not.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he left them, he said, (“I must go to the special supper at Jerusalem.) I will return again to you if God wants me to.” Then he got on a ship and left Ephesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stopped in the city of Caesarea to greet the people in the church. Then he went down to the city of Antioch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul stayed there for some time. Then he went from city to city through the countries of Galatia and Phrygia. In each place he helped the Christians become strong in the faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: A Jew by the name of Apollos had come to Ephesus. He was from the city of Alexandria. He could talk to people about the Holy Writings very well.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had been taught in the way of the Lord. And with a strong desire in his heart, he taught about Jesus. What he said was true, but he knew only about the baptism of John.
speaker: Narrator

text: He began to speak without fear in the Jewish place of worship. Aquila and Priscilla heard him. They took him to their house and taught him much more about the things of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Apollos wanted to cross over to Greece. The Christians wrote a letter to the followers there asking them to be good to him. When he got there, he was much help to those who had put their trust in Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: In front of everyone he proved with great power that the Jews were wrong. He showed from the Holy Writings that Jesus was the Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Apollos was in the city of Corinth, Paul went through the hill country to get to the city of Ephesus. He found a few followers there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you put your trust in Christ?” They said, “No, we have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, “How were you baptized?” They answered, “The way John baptized.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “John baptized those who were sorry for their sins and turned from them. He told the people to put their trust in Jesus Who was coming later.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people there were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus when they heard this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them. They started to talk in special sounds and to speak God’s Word.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were about twelve men.
speaker: Narrator

text: For three months Paul went into the Jewish place of worship and spoke without fear. He taught them things about the holy nation of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some let their hearts grow hard. They would not put their trust in Christ. These spoke against the Christian religion in front of other people. Then Paul took the followers away from the others. He taught them each day in the school of Tyrannus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this for two years. All the Jews and the Greeks in the countries of Asia heard the Word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: God used Paul to do powerful special works.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pieces of cloth and parts of his clothes that had been next to his body were put on sick people. Then they were healed of their diseases and demons came out of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were Jews who went from city to city trying to put demons out of people. Some of these tried to use the name of the Lord Jesus on those who had demons. They said, “I speak to you in the name of Jesus, the One Paul preaches about.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A Jewish leader of the people by the name of Sceva had seven sons. These sons were trying to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: The demon said, “I know Jesus. I know about Paul. But who are you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man with the demon jumped on the sons. He had power over them and beat them. They ran out of the house with no clothes on and they were hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Jews and Greeks living in Ephesus heard about it. Because of this all the people became afraid. And the name of the Lord Jesus was held in great honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many Christians came and told of the wrong things they were doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of those who did witchcraft gathered their books together and burned them in front of everyone. These books were worth 50,000 pieces of silver money.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Word of the Lord became well-known.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Paul thought he would go through the countries of Macedonia and Greece. Then he would go to Jerusalem. He said, “After I have been there, I must go to the city of Rome also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia. Paul stayed in the countries of Asia awhile longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: During that time there was much trouble about the Christians.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man named Demetrius made small silver buildings for the worship of Diana. His workmen received much money for their work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called his workmen together and other men who made these small silver buildings. He said to them, “Men, you know we make much money from this work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you hear that Paul has turned away many people in Ephesus as well as in Asia. He tells them that gods made with hands are not gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: It could be that our work will not be respected. Not only that, the house of worship for the god of Diana will be worth nothing and her greatness will be destroyed. All the countries of Asia and the world worship her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They became angry when they heard this and cried out, “Great is Diana of Ephesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole city was filled with loud cries. They caught Gaius and Aristarchus. These two men from Macedonia were with Paul. They gathered around them at the meeting place in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul wanted to stand in front of all the people but his followers would not let him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the city leaders who were his friends told him not to go to the meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: All this time some were crying out one thing and some another. The meeting was all noise. Most of the people did not know why they had come together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Jews pushed Alexander to the front. Alexander held his hand up and was going to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as they saw he was a Jew, they cried out with a loud voice for two hours, “Great is Diana of Ephesus!”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the city leaders stopped the noise. He spoke, “Men of Ephesus, everyone knows our city is where the god of Diana is kept. That is the stone god that fell from the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone knows this is true, so you must not cry out or do anything foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men you brought here do not rob houses of worship or talk against our god.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Demetrius and his workmen have something against anyone, we have special days for courts. Let them go to court.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you want anything else, it should be done in another meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are in danger of being asked about this trouble today. There is no good reason we can give for this meeting.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had said this, he told them to leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the noise had come to an end, Paul called the followers to him. He spoke words of comfort and then said good-bye. He left to go to the country of Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he went through those parts of the country, he spoke words of comfort and help to the Christians. Then he went on to the country of Greece.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stayed there three months. As he was about to get on a ship for the country of Syria, he learned that the Jews had made a plan to take him. He changed his plans and went back through Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men were going along with him. They were Sopater of the city of Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus of the city of Thessalonica, Gaius of the city of Derbe, and Timothy and Tychicus and Trophimus of the countries of Asia.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went on to the city of Troas and waited there for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the supper of bread without yeast we got on a ship in the city of Philippi. We met these men at Troas. It took five days to get there and we stayed one week.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the week we met together to eat the Lord’s supper. Paul talked to them. He thought he would leave the next day, so he kept on talking until twelve o’clock at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were many lights in the room on the third floor where we had our meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young man named Eutychus sat in the window. As Paul kept on preaching, this man started to go to sleep. At last he went to sleep. He fell from the third floor to the ground and was picked up dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went down and stood over him. Then he took him in his arms and said, “Do not be worried. He is alive!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul went up again to the meeting and ate with them. He talked with them until the sun came up. Then he left.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were happy they could take the young man home alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: We went on ahead by ship to the city of Assos. There we were to pick up Paul. He had planned it that way. He wanted to walk by land that far.
speaker: Narrator

text: We got to Assos and met him there. We picked him up and went on to the city of Mitylene.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we went by ship to a place beside the island of Chios. The next day we crossed over to the island of Samos. Then the next day we came to the city of Miletus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul planned to pass by the city of Ephesus so he would not lose more time in Asia. He wanted to be in Jerusalem if he could be on the day to remember how the Holy Spirit came on the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Miletus he sent word to Ephesus. He asked the leaders of the church to come to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they got there, he said to them, “From the first day that I came to Asia you have seen what my life has been like.
speaker: Narrator

text: I worked for the Lord without pride. Because of the trouble the Jews gave me, I have had many tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: I always told you everything that would be a help to you. I taught you in open meetings and from house to house.
speaker: Narrator

text: I preached to the Jews and to the Greeks. I told them to turn from their sin to God and to put their trust in our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As you see, I am on my way to Jerusalem. The Holy Spirit makes me go. I do not know what will happen to me there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in every city I have been, the Holy Spirit tells me that trouble and chains will be waiting for me there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I am not worried about this. I do not think of my life as worth much, but I do want to finish the work the Lord Jesus gave me to do. My work is to preach the Good News of God’s loving-favor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All of you have heard me preach the Good News. I am sure that none of you will ever see my face again.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you this day that I am clean and free from the blood of all men.
speaker: Narrator

text: I told you all the truth about God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep a careful watch over yourselves and over the church. The Holy Spirit has made you its leaders. Feed and care for the church of God. He bought it with His own blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes, I know that when I am gone, hungry wolves will come in among you. They will try to destroy the church.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also men from your own group will begin to teach things that are not true. They will get men to follow them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I say again, keep watching! Remember that for three years I taught everyone of you night and day, even with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, my brothers, I give you over to God and to the word of His love. It is able to make you strong and to give you what you are to have, along with all those who are set apart for God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not tried to get anyone’s money or clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You all know that these hands worked for what I needed and for what those with me needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every way I showed you that by working hard like this we can help those who are weak. We must remember what the Lord Jesus said, ‘We are more happy when we give than when we receive.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he finished talking, he got down on his knees and prayed with them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried and put their arms around Paul and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: What made them sad most of all was he said that they would never see his face again. Then they went with him to the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we left them, we got on a ship and came straight down to the island of Cos. The next day we came to the island of Rhodes and from there to the city of Patara.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we found a ship that was going over to the country of Phoenicia. We got on it and went along.
speaker: Narrator

text: We saw the island of Cyprus to our left but went on to the country of Syria. We came to land at the city of Tyre. The ship was to leave its load of freight there.
speaker: Narrator

text: We looked for the Christians and stayed with them seven days. The Christians had been told by the Holy Spirit to tell Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When our time was up, we left there and went on our way. All of them with their wives and children went with us out of town. They got down on their knees on the shore and prayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we said good-bye, we got on the ship and they went back to their houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same ship took us from Tyre to the city of Ptolemais. We stayed with the Christians there one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we left and came to the city of Caesarea. We went to the house of Philip and stayed with him. He was a preacher who goes from town to town and was one of the seven church leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Philip had four daughters who were not married. They spoke the Word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: While we were there a few days, a man who speaks for God named Agabus came down from the country of Judea.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to see us. Then he took Paul’s belt and used it to tie his own feet and hands. He said, “This is what the Holy Spirit says, ‘The Jews at Jerusalem will tie the man who owns this belt. Then they will hand him over to the people who are not Jews.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When we heard this, we and all the people living there begged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul said, “What do you mean by crying and breaking my heart? I am ready to be put in chains in Jerusalem. I am also ready to die for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul would not listen to us. So we stopped begging him and said, “May whatever God wants be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, we got ready and started up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the followers in Caesarea went with us. They took us to Mnason’s house. He was one of the first followers from Cyprus. We stayed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we got to Jerusalem, the Christians were glad to see us.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we went with Paul to see James. All the church leaders came also.
speaker: Narrator

text: After saying hello to them, Paul told of what God had done through his work for the people who were not Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, they thanked the Lord. Then they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands of Christians there are among the Jews. They all obey the Law of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have heard about you. They have heard you teach the Jews who live among people who are not Jews. They have heard you teach them to break away from the Law of Moses. They say you are telling them not to do the religious act of becoming a Jew and not to follow old religious ways of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: What should we do about it? They will hear that you have come.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must do what we tell you. We have four men with us who have made a promise to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take these four men and go through the religious worship of washing with them. You pay to have their hair cut off. Then everybody will know what they have heard about you is not true. They will know you are careful to obey the Law of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the people who are not Jews, we wrote to them. We said that they must keep away from everything that has been given to gods. They must not eat blood or meat from animals that have been killed in ways against the Law. They must keep away from sex sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Paul took the men. He went through the religious worship of washing with them. They went into the house of God to tell when their religious worship of washing would be finished. Then the gift for each one of them would be given as an act of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven days were almost finished. Jews from the countries of Asia saw Paul in the house of God. They made the people turn against him. Then they took hold of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried out, “You who are Jews, help us! This is the man who is teaching against our people and our Law and this house of God. Also he has brought Greek people into the house of God. This has made this holy place unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They had seen him before in the city with Trophimus who was from the city of Ephesus. They thought Paul had brought him into the house of God also.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people in the city were crying out with loud voices. The people pushed and moved together. They took Paul and dragged him out of the house of God. Then the doors were shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were getting ready to kill him. The captain of the soldiers heard there was trouble over all Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: At once the captain called his soldiers and they ran down to the people. When the people saw the captain and his soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain came and took hold of Paul. He told his soldiers to tie Paul with two chains. Then he asked who he was and what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the people called out one thing and some another. The captain was not able to find out what had happened. He told his men to take Paul into the soldiers’ building.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people cried out so loud and pushed so hard that Paul had to be carried up the steps by the soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people kept pushing and calling out, “Kill him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul was brought into the soldiers’ building. He said to the captain, “May I say something to you?” The captain said, “Can you speak the Greek language?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you not the man from the country of Egypt who made trouble against our country? That man led 4,000 fighting men into the desert.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “No! I am a Jew and a citizen of a large city. I am from Tarsus in the country of Cilicia. I ask you to let me speak to the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain told Paul to speak. So Paul stood on the steps and held up his hand. When there was no more noise, he spoke to them in the language of the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “Brothers and fathers, listen to what I have to say to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard him speak to them in their own language, they stopped making noise. Then he said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am a Jew. I was born in the city of Tarsus in the country of Cilicia. When I was a young man, I lived here in Jerusalem. I went to Gamaliel’s school and learned all about the Law of our early fathers. I worked hard for God as you all do today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I worked hard and killed men and women who believed as I believe today. I put them in chains and sent them to prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: The head religious leader and the leaders of the people can tell you this is true. I got letters from them to take to our Jewish brothers in the city of Damascus. I was going there to put the Christians in chains and bring them to Jerusalem where they would be beaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I was near Damascus. All at once, about noon, I saw a bright light from heaven shining around me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fell to the ground. A voice said to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why do you work so hard against Me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: I said, ‘Who are You, Lord?’ He said to me, ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, the One you are working against.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were with me saw the light. But they did not hear Him speaking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I asked, ‘Lord, what should I do?’ The Lord said to me, ‘Get up! Go to Damascus. You will be told what to do there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I could not see because of the bright light. Those who were with me had to lead me by the hand until we came to Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ananias lived there. He obeyed the Law and was respected by all the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came and stood near me and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight.’ At once I was able to see him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ananias said, ‘The God of our fathers chose you to know what He wants done. He chose you to see Jesus Christ, the One Right with God, and to hear His voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to tell all men what you have seen and heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: What are you waiting for? Get up! Be baptized. Have your sins washed away by calling on His name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I came back to Jerusalem. When I was praying in the house of God, I had a dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw Him as He said to me, ‘Get out of Jerusalem! They will not listen to you when you tell them about Me!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I said, ‘Lord, they know I took Christians out of every Jewish place of worship. I had them beaten and put in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also when Stephen was killed, I stood there and watched them throw stones at him. Those who threw the stones had me watch their coats.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, ‘Go! I will send you far away to the people who are not Jews.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: They listened to him until he said that. Then they all cried out with loud voices, “Kill him! Take such a man from the earth! He should not live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They kept on calling out. Then they pulled off their coats and threw dust in the air.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain told them to bring Paul into the soldiers’ building. He told his soldiers to find out from Paul, by beating him, why the people were crying out against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they tied him up, Paul said to the soldier, “Does the law say that you can beat a Roman citizen when no one has said he is guilty?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the soldier heard this, he told it to the captain. He said, “Listen! What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain came and asked Paul, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?” Paul said, “Yes!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain said, “I had to pay a lot of money to be a citizen.” Paul said, “But I was born a Roman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were going to beat him left him at once. The captain was also afraid when he heard that Paul was a Roman citizen because he had him tied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day they took off the chains that were holding Paul. The captain wanted to know why the Jews wanted to kill him. So the captain told the head religious leaders to gather for their court. They brought Paul and put him in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul looked straight at the court and said, “Brother Jews, I have lived for God with a heart that has said I am not guilty to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ananias, the head religious leader, told those standing near him to hit him on the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “God will hit you, you white-washed wall! Do you sit there and say I am guilty by the Law when you break the Law by having me hit?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those standing near said, “Do you talk like that to God’s head religious leader?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “Brother Jews, I did not know that he was God’s head religious leader. I know the Holy Writings say, ‘You must not speak against the leader of your people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul saw that part of the court was made up of the religious group who believe no one is raised from the dead. The other part were proud religious law-keepers. Then he cried out, “Brother Jews, I am a proud religious law-keeper and from a family of proud religious law-keepers. I have been brought in front of this court because of the hope of being raised from the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, both religious groups started to argue and the people of the court were divided in what they thought.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one religious group believes that no one is raised from the dead. Also, they do not believe in angels or spirits. But the other religious group, the proud religious law-keepers, believe that people are raised from the dead and that there are angels and spirits.
speaker: Narrator

text: The courtroom was filled with noise. Some of the teachers of the Law working with the proud religious law-keepers stood up and said, “We find nothing wrong with this man. What if an angel or spirit has spoken to him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They argued all the more. Then the captain was afraid they would pull Paul to pieces. He told his men to get Paul out of there and take him back to the soldiers’ building.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next night the Lord came to Paul and said, “Paul, do not be afraid! You will tell about Me in the city of Rome the same as you have told about Me in Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning some of the Jews gathered together and made a plan to kill Paul. They promised each other that they would not eat or drink until they had killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were more than forty of them who had made this promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: These people came to the head religious leader and to the leaders of the people and said, “We have made a promise not to eat any food until we have killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: We ask you and the court to have the captain bring Paul down to you tomorrow. It will look as if you want to ask him some things. Before he gets near you, we will be waiting to kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul’s nephew heard about the plan. He went to the soldiers’ building and told Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul called one of the soldiers and said, “Take this young man to the captain. He has something to tell him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers brought the young man to the captain and said, “Paul asked me to bring this young man to you. He has something to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain took him by the hand and they walked over where they could be alone. He said, “What is it that you have to tell me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man said, “The Jews have made a plan to ask you to bring Paul to the courtroom tomorrow. It would look as if they were going to ask him some things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let them talk you into it. More than forty men are waiting in secret to kill him. They have promised each other not to eat or drink anything until they have killed him. They are all waiting for you to say the word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain told the young man to go. He said, “Do not tell anyone you have told me this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the captain called two soldiers and said, “Get 200 men ready to go to the city of Caesarea by nine o’clock tonight. Also have seventy men ride on horses and 200 men carry spears.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get horses ready for Paul to ride. Take him to Felix, the leader of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He wrote a letter which said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Claudius Lysias greets Felix, the best leader of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man Paul was taken by the Jews. He was about to be killed by them. But I came along with my soldiers and kept him from being killed. I did this when I learned that he was a Roman citizen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wanted to know what they had against him. So I took him to the religious leaders’ court.
speaker: Narrator

text: I learned they were holding him because of something about their Law. There was no reason for him to be killed or to be put in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was told that the Jews had a plan to kill this man. At once I sent him to you. I told the Jews who wanted to kill him to tell you what they have against him. Good-bye.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers took Paul as they were told. They brought him during the night to Antipatris.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day they went back to their building in Jerusalem. The men riding horses went on with Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Caesarea, they gave the letter to the leader of the people. They also handed Paul over to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he read the letter, he asked what part of the country Paul was from. He was told that Paul was from the city of Cilicia.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “I will listen to all of this when the men come who want to kill you.” He had Paul kept in King Herod’s building.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five days later Ananias came to the city of Caesarea. He was the head religious leader. Some other religious leaders and a man whose name was Tertullus came also. This man worked in courts and knew all about the laws. He told Felix what the Jews had against Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They brought in Paul. Then Tertullus started to tell what the Jews had against him, saying,
“Most respected Felix, because of you, we are living in peace. Wrong-doings have been made right in this nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: In every way and in every place, we thank you for all of this.
speaker: Narrator

text: We do not want to keep you here too long. I ask you to listen to our few words. You are known to be kind in this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have found this man to be a trouble-maker among all the Jews in the world. He is a leader of a religious group called the Nazarenes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He even tried to make the house of God unclean by taking people into it who were not Jews. But we took hold of him. (We could have said he was guilty by our Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lysias, the captain, came and took him out of our hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told those who wanted to kill him to tell you what they had against him.) When you ask him about these things, you will be able to learn everything we have against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews agreed to what he said against Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Felix, the leader of the people, told Paul to speak. Paul said, “I know that you have been a leader of this nation for many years. I am happy to be able to speak for myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not more than twelve days ago I went up to Jerusalem to worship. You can find out about this yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did not argue with anyone in the house of God or in the Jewish places of worship or in the city. I was not making trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cannot prove any of these things they say against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will say this, I worship the God of our fathers in the new Way. They say it is a false way. But I believe everything that has been written in the Law and by the early preachers.
speaker: Narrator

text: I trust God for the same things they are looking for. I am looking for the dead to rise, both those right with God and the sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: I always try to live so my own heart tells me I am not guilty before God or man.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After a few years I came to bring gifts of money to the people of my country (Jerusalem).
speaker: Narrator

text: Some Jews from the countries of Asia found me in the house of God after I had gone through the worship of washing. There were no people around me and there was no noise or fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: They should be here if they have anything against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or let these men tell what wrong they found in me as I stood in front of their court,
speaker: Narrator

text: unless it was the words I cried out as I stood in front of them. I said, ‘I have been brought in front of this court because of the hope of being raised from the dead.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Felix knew about the Christian religion. He stopped the court, saying, “When Lysias the captain comes down, I will decide about this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the soldier to watch Paul, but to let him come and go as much as he wanted to. Paul’s friends were to be able to come and care for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some days later Felix came again. His Jewish wife Drusilla was with him. He sent for Paul and heard him talk about faith in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul spoke about being right with God. He spoke about being the boss over our own desires. He spoke about standing before One Who will tell us if we are guilty. When Felix heard this, he became afraid and said, “Go now. I will send for you when it is a better time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He was hoping that Paul would give him money so he could go free. For that reason he kept sending for Paul and talking to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After two years Porcius Festus became leader of the people instead of Felix. Felix wanted to please the Jews so he kept Paul in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after Festus had become leader in the country, he went from the city of Caesarea to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The head religious leaders and the leaders of the Jews told Festus what they had against Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked Festus for a favor. They wanted Paul to be brought to Jerusalem because they had plans to kill him on the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus told them that Paul was to be kept in Caesarea and that he would be going there soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus said, “If Paul has done anything wrong, let your leaders go along with me and say what they have against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After staying with them about ten days, Festus went down to Caesarea. The next day he sat in the courtroom and asked for Paul to be brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul came into the courtroom. The Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him. They said many bad things against him. But they could not prove any of the things they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul spoke for himself, saying, “I have done nothing wrong against the Law of the Jews or against the house of God or against Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus was hoping to get the respect of the Jews. He asked Paul, “Will you go to the court in Jerusalem and let me say if you are guilty or not about these things?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “I am standing in front of Caesar’s court where I should be told I am right or wrong. I have done no wrong to the Jews. You know that.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have done wrong and should die, I am not trying to keep from dying. But if these things they say against me are not true, no one can give me over to them. I ask to be taken to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus talked to the leaders of the court. Then he said to Paul, “You have asked to be taken to Caesar. You will go to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After a few days, King Agrippa and his wife, Bernice, came down to Caesarea. They went to Festus to greet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stayed there a few days. Festus told them about Paul. He said, “There is a man here who was left in prison by Felix.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I was at Jerusalem, the head religious leaders and the leaders of the people told me about him and asked me to say that he is guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: I told them it was against the Roman law to hand over a man to be put to death before he stood face to face with those who had something against him and could speak for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came here, I took my seat in the courtroom at once. I had the man brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the others spoke, they had nothing against him that I thought they had.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not agree with him about their own religion, and they argued about someone called Jesus. He had died but Paul kept saying He was alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did not know what to do. Then I asked him if he would go on trial about these things at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul asked to go on trial in front of Caesar. I said that he should be kept in prison until he could be sent to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Agrippa said to Festus, “I would like to hear this man.” Festus said, “Tomorrow you will hear him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Agrippa and Bernice came into the courtroom. They were dressed to show their greatness as king and queen. Army leaders and leading men of the city came in with them. Festus had Paul brought in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Festus said, “King Agrippa and all of you who are here with us, you see this man. All of the Jews both here and at Jerusalem are saying that Paul should be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard nothing against him that would be reason to put him to death. But he asked for a trial in front of Caesar. I have agreed to send Paul to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I write to Caesar, I have nothing to say against him. For this reason, I brought him in front of you all and in front of you, King Agrippa. After we ask him questions, I may have something to write about.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is foolish for me to send a man up for trial without writing what is against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Agrippa said to Paul, “You may now speak for yourself.” Paul lifted his hand and started to talk,
speaker: Narrator

text: “King Agrippa, the Jews have said many things against me. I am happy to be able to tell you my side of the story.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know all about the Jewish ways and problems. So I ask you to listen to me until I have finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All the Jews know about my life from the time I was a boy until now. I lived among my own people in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they would tell what they know, they would say that I lived the life of a proud religious law-keeper. I was in the group of proud religious law-keepers who tried to obey every law.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now I am on trial here because I trust the promise God made to our fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: This promise is what our twelve family groups of the Jewish nation hope to see happen. They worship God day and night. King Agrippa, it is because of this hope that they are saying things against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you think it is hard to believe that God raises people from the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: “I used to think I should work hard against the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did that in Jerusalem. I put many of the followers in prison. The head religious leaders gave me the right and the power to do it. Then when the followers were killed, I said it was all right.
speaker: Narrator

text: I beat them and tried to make them speak against God in all the Jewish places of worship. In my fight against them, I kept going after them even into cities in other countries.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When I was going to Damascus to do this, I had the right and the power from the head religious leaders to make it hard for the followers.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was on the road at noon. King Agrippa, I saw a light from heaven brighter than the sun. It was shining around me and the men with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: We all fell to the ground. Then I heard a voice speaking to me in the Jewish language, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you working so hard against Me? You hurt yourself by trying to hurt Me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I said, ‘Who are You, Lord?’ And He said, ‘I am Jesus, the One you are working against.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up. Stand on your feet. I have chosen you to work for Me. You will tell what you have seen and you will say what I want you to say. This is the reason I have allowed you to see Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will keep you safe from the Jews and from the people who are not Jews. I am sending you to these people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to open their eyes. You are to turn them from darkness to light. You are to turn them from the power of Satan to the power of God. In this way, they may have their sins forgiven. They may have what is given to them, along with all those who are set apart for God by having faith in Me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “King Agrippa, I obeyed what I saw from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: First I told what I saw to those in Damascus and then in Jerusalem. I told it through all the country of Judea. I even preached to the people who are not Jews that they should be sorry for their sins and turn from them to God. I told them they should do things to show they are sorry for their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why the Jews took hold of me in the house of God and tried to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has helped me. To this day I have told these things to the people who are well-known and to those not known. I have told only what the early preachers and Moses said would happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was that Christ must suffer and be the first to rise from the dead. He would give light to the Jews and to the other nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Paul was speaking for himself, Festus cried out in a loud voice, “Paul, you are crazy! All your learning keeps you from thinking right!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “Most respected Festus, I am not crazy. I am speaking the truth!
speaker: Narrator

text: The king knows about all this. I am free to speak to him in plain words. Nothing I have said is new to him. These things happened where everyone saw them.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa, do you believe the writings of the early preachers? I know that you believe them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “In this short time you have almost proven to me that I should become a Christian!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said, “My prayer to God is that you and all who hear me today would be a Christian as I am, only not have these chains!”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa and Festus and Bernice and those who sat with them got up.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they left the courtroom, they said to each other, “This man has done nothing for which he should be kept in prison or be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Agrippa told Festus, “This man could go free if he had not asked to be sent to Caesar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was decided that we should go to the country of Italy by ship. Then they put Paul and some other men in chains. Julius, a captain of Caesar’s army, was to watch them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We went on a ship that was from the city of Adramyttian. It was going to stop at the towns along the sea-shore of Asia. Aristarchus was with us. He was a man from the city of Thessalonica in the country of Macedonia.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day we stopped in the city of Sidon. Julius was kind to Paul. He let him visit friends who cared for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After leaving Sidon we were blown by the wind along the south side of the island of Cyprus. The wind was against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We crossed the sea along the countries of Cilicia and Pamphylia and got to the city of Myra in the country of Lycia.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain found a ship from the city of Alexandria that was going to the country of Italy. He put us on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For many days the ship did not move fast. It was hard to get to the city of Cnidus. The wind would not let us go on. So we went along the south shore of the island of Crete and passed the end of the island called Salome.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wind was against us, and we did not sail very fast. Then we came to a place called Fair Havens. It was near the city of Lasea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Much time had been lost. To keep going that late in the year would mean danger. Paul spoke with strong words,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sirs, it looks to me as if this ship and its freight will be lost. We are in danger of being lost also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the soldiers listened to what the captain of the ship said and not to what Paul said.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was not a good place to spend the winter. Most of those on the ship wanted to go on and try to get to Phoenix. Crete was a good place to tie up the ship. They wanted to spend the winter there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a south wind started to blow, they thought their plan was right. They pulled up the anchor and went close to the shore of Crete.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later a bad wind storm came down from the land. It was called a northeaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ship was stopped by the wind. After awhile we gave up and let it go with the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: We went behind a small island called Claudia. It was hard work but we were able to make the ship’s boat safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: They pulled it up and tied ropes around it and the ship. They were afraid of going on the Syrtis sands. So they took the sail down and let the ship go with the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The storm was so bad the high waves were beating against the ship. The next day the men threw some of the freight over into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, with their own hands, they threw part of the sails and ropes into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: We did not see the sun or stars for many days. A very bad storm kept beating against us. We lost all hope of being saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one had eaten for a long time. Then Paul stood up and said to them, “Men, you should have listened to me and not left Crete. You would not have had this trouble and loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now I want you to take hope. No one will lose his life. Only the ship will be lost.
speaker: Narrator

text: I belong to God and I work for Him. Last night an angel of God stood by me
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand in front of Caesar. God has given you the lives of all the men on this ship.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So take hope, men. I believe my God will do what He has told me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the ship will be lost on some island.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was now the fourteenth night. We were going with the wind on the Adriatic Sea. At midnight the sailors thought land was near.
speaker: Narrator

text: They let down the lead weight and found the water was not very deep. After they had gone a little farther, they found there was not as much water.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were afraid we might be thrown against the rocks on the shore. So they put out four anchors from the back of the ship. Then they waited for morning to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sailors were thinking of leaving the ship. They let down a boat as if they were going to put out anchors from the front of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said to the captain and the soldiers, “These men must stay on the ship or you cannot be safe!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the soldiers cut the ropes and let the boat fall into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just before the light of day came, Paul told all of them to eat. He said, “Today is the fourteenth day you have not eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must eat. It will give you strength. Not one of you will lose a hair from your head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he said this, he took some bread. He gave thanks to God in front of them all. He broke it in pieces and started to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all were comforted. Each one ate some food.
speaker: Narrator

text: All together there were 276 of us on the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had eaten, they threw the wheat into the sea so the ship would not be as heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning they could not see what land they were near. Later they could see a river. Near its mouth there was a shore of sand. They planned to run the ship onto the sand if they could.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anchors were cut loose and left in the sea. Then they took the ropes off that were holding the rudder. When they put up the sail, the wind took the ship toward shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the ship hit a place where the water was low. It was made from where two seas meet. The front of the ship did not move but the back part broke in pieces by the high waves.
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers planned to kill the men in chains. They were afraid they would swim to shore and get away,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the captain wanted to save Paul. He kept them from their plan. Calling out to those who could swim, he told them to jump into the sea and swim to shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: The others should use wood or anything from the ship. In this way, they all got to shore without getting hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text: After we were safe on the island, we knew that it was Malta.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people on the island were very kind to us. It was raining and cold. They made a fire so we could get warm.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul had gathered some wood. As he laid it on the fire, a snake came out because of the heat. It held fast to Paul’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of the island saw the snake holding to his hand, they said to each other, “This man is a killer. He was saved from the sea and yet it is not right for him to live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul shook off the snake into the fire. He was not hurt in any way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people waited. They thought his hand would get large and he would fall over dead. After watching for a long time, they saw nothing happen to him. Then they changed their minds and said that Paul was a god.
speaker: Narrator

text: Publius was the head man of the island. He owned land around there. For three days he took us in and gave us everything we needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The father of Publius was sick with a stomach sickness. Paul went to see him. He prayed and laid his hands on him and the man was healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this, other people of the island who were sick came to Paul and were healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had great respect for us. When we got into a ship to leave, they gave us everything we needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had stayed on the island three months. Then we left on a ship that had stayed there during the winter. It was from the city of Alexandria. This ship was called the Twin Brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: We came to Syracuse and stayed there three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there we went by ship around to the city of Rhegium. After a day a south wind started to blow. On the second day we came to the city of Puteoli.
speaker: Narrator

text: We found some Christians there, and they asked us to stay with them. We were there seven days and then went on to the city of Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Christians heard of our coming, they came to meet us. They came as far as the town of Appius and to a place to stay called the Three Stores. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we got to Rome, Paul was allowed to live where he wanted to. But a soldier was always by his side to watch him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later Paul asked the leaders of the Jews to come to him. When they had gathered together, he said, “Brothers, I have done nothing against our people or the way our early fathers lived. And yet, I was tied with chains in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was put on trial, but they found no reason to put me to death. They would have let me go free.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Jews did not like this. So I had to ask to be sent to Caesar. It was not because I had anything against my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The reason I have asked you to come is to tell you this. It is because of the hope of the Jewish nation that I am tied in these chains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Paul, “We have had no letters from Judea about you. No Jew who has come here has ever said anything bad about you.
speaker: Narrator

text: We would like to hear from you what you believe. As for this new religion, all we know is that everyone is talking against it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They planned to meet him on a certain day. Many people came to the place where he stayed. He preached to them about the holy nation of God. He tried to get them to put their trust in Jesus Christ by preaching from the Law of Moses and from the writings of the early preachers. From morning until night he spoke to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of them believed his teaching. Others did not believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they left, they did not agree with each other. Then Paul said, “The Holy Spirit spoke the truth to your early fathers through the early preacher Isaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘Go to these people and say, “You will hear and never understand, you will look and never see,
speaker: Narrator

text: because these people have hearts that have become fat. They do not hear well with their ears. They have closed their eyes so their eyes do not see and their ears do not hear and their minds do not understand and they do not turn to Me and let Me heal them.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I want you to know that the Good News of God of knowing how to be saved from the punishment of sin has been sent to the people who are not Jews. And they will listen to it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had said these things, the Jews went away and argued with each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul paid money to live in a house by himself for two years. He was happy for all who came to see him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He kept on preaching about the holy nation of God. He taught about the Lord Jesus Christ without fear. No one stopped him.
speaker: Narrator
